text: György Marx (May 25, 1927, Budapest, Hungary – December 2, 2002, ibidem) was a Hungarian physicist, astrophysicist, science historian and professor. He discovered the lepton numbers and established the law of lepton flavor conservation.Megemlékezés - MARX GYÖRGY (1927-2002) - Sándor Szalay, András Patkós - Hungarian Academy of Sciences, 2003/4 ==Life== He was the first non- British laureate of the Bragg MedalBragg medal recipients, retrieved 2019-08-24. of the Institute of Physics, in 2001. He received it for his "outstanding contributions to physics education".Abstract - Life in the nuclear valley - George Marx ==Death== The tomb of György Marx and his parents in the Farkasréti Cemetery (30/2-1-3.) Marx died on the December 2, 2002 in Budapest after a serious illness. On December 18 he was buried at the Farkasréti Cemetery with Reformed ceremony in the presence of his family, friends, disciples, colleagues and fellow scientists. Szilveszter E.
